newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Stanchart bank ordered to pay damages in Jakarta.
newsitem.headline: Stanchart bank ordered to pay damages in Jakarta.

text.p: An Indonesian court on Friday ordered Standard Chartered Bank to pay a Hong Kong businesswoman 247.9 million rupiah ($106,440) after she sued the bank's Jakarta branch for freezing her account.
Judge Zulkifli Lubis of the Central Jakarta State Court ordered the bank to pay Yee Mei-Mei 150 million rupiah for "moral losses" and 97.9 million rupiah in interest for the frozen funds.
"We have to protect the rights of the community when depositing money," Lubis said in handing down his verdict.
In a statement issued following the judgement, the bank said it was considering its position.
"Standard Chartered Plc has maintained throughout this court case that it acted properly and in accordance with both regulatory obligations and best banking practice," it said.

Yee, a representative of Dragon Bank International of Vanuatu, obtained a temporary court order against Standard Chartered's Jakarta Branch in April after it refused to honour five cheques totalling about 979 million rupiah.
She had also asked for $300 million in damages because she claimed the bank had defamed her by freezing the money after its internal money-laundering procedures had been alerted.
The bank said in its statement that a court decree attaching certain assets of the Jakarta branch had been revoked.
Lubis said the case was a personal one and refused to recognise that the Dragon Bank had suffered any losses.
Indonesia's Investment Coordinating Board said in June it had cancelled Dragon Bank's investment licence because its operations were not in line with its licence.
